{"step_by_step_thinking": "Benign intracranial hypertension, also known as pseudotumor cerebri, is a condition characterized by increased pressure in the brain without a clear cause. The common features of this condition include headache, papilledema (swelling of the optic disc), and normal size ventricles because the pressure increase is not due to a mass effect. Proptosis, or bulging eyes, is not a typical feature of benign intracranial hypertension.", "answer_choice": "A"}
